newsitem.title: YUGOSLAVIA: Many Yugoslav firms say economic climate bad.
newsitem.headline: Many Yugoslav firms say economic climate bad.

text.p: Yugoslavia's business climate deteriorated in March and industry is mixed on the immediate outlook, according to a poll conducted by a Belgrade-based economic think-tank.

"Only a negligible 0.2 percent of firms polled believe the present overall economic situation is good while 64.1 percent think it is bad," Goran Pitic, a prominent economist with the Economics Institute, said on Thursday.
The institute provided no figures for other answers. It conducts monthly polls of 300 Yugoslav firms covering 55 percent of all industry.
On the short-term outlook, 22.2 percent of those polled saw the situation improving and 18.1 percent said it would worsen, the report said.
Optimism on production activity was low, with 17.4 percent of polled companies reporting growth in March, while 15.6 percent said their output had dropped.
The firms cited lack of credits, low demand and shortage of imports as major factors inhibiting growth.
Lack of demand is a problem for many firms, with only 30.5 percent envisaging increased domestic sales in the second quarter.
